summary: This document is a chain of internal emails from February 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff discussing FOIA litigation brought by The New York Times against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP). The Times sought records related to Jeffrey Epstein, and BOP had categorically refused to produce any documents, citing multiple FOIA exemptions due to ongoing investigations into Epstein's death. The emails coordinate a meeting to discuss the case and the government's response strategy.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney for the plaintiff (The New York Times) in the FOIA litigation against BOP; mentioned as the point of contact for the civil side.

events.title: FOIA Answer Deadline
events.description: Deadline for the government to file an Answer in the FOIA lawsuit brought by The New York Times against BOP regarding Jeffrey Epstein records.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date
events.description: Mentioned trial date for the FOIA litigation between The New York Times and BOP.

events.title: Scheduled Meeting on FOIA Requests
events.description: Planned meeting among SDNY AUSAs to discuss FOIA requests related to Jeffrey Epstein from The New York Times.

keyFacts: The New York Times filed a FOIA lawsuit against the Bureau of Prisons (BOP) seeking records related to Jeffrey Epstein.
BOP categorically refused to provide any documents in response, asserting FOIA Exemptions 5, 6, 7(A), 7(C), 7(E), and 7(F), citing ongoing investigations into Epstein's death.
The government's response deadline (Answer) was March 4, 2020, with a trial scheduled for June 20, 2020.
Internal emails discuss strategy, noting that categorical refusals can be difficult to defend but are allowed under certain exemptions.
The correspondence references the use of Touhy regulations to handle third-party discovery demands for information from the Department of Justice.
